Award.AwardTitle: Exploring the Relationship between Vibratory Roller-Based

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
Vibratory roller-based measurement of soil properties (namely soil stiffness) during and after compaction (often referred to as intelligent compaction) offers an exceptionally promising tool to improve the construction and thus performance of earth structures (e.g., embankments, earth dams, levees, pavement & railway foundations). This grant provides funding for the creation, calibration, and validation of finite element models to interpret of vibratory roller-measured data generated in intelligent earthwork compaction procedures. The research approach will involve experimental and numerical modeling programs to quantify the relationships between real-time vibratory roller measurements and the dynamic material properties of layered compacted soil foundations. The experimental program will utilize instrumented vibratory rollers to collect force-deflection measurements on 12 configurations of layered soils; in-situ triaxial accelerometers will be used to measure subsurface dynamic response. A resonant column device will also be used to quantify the stress and strain-dependent elastic moduli and viscous damping ratios of the component soils in a controlled laboratory environment. The numerical modeling program will involve dynamic finite element simulations of the 12 field configurations, using the soils' dynamic properties, the measured roller/soil contact area, and roller loading as input and the field accelerations and force-deflection measurements as output for calibration and validation.
The research aims to advance efforts in intelligent construction by relating real-time construction monitoring to constitutive, performance-related soil parameters. The estimation of a soil?s elastic stiffness through vibratory roller-measured data can be directly related to designed-for properties of earth structures; performance criteria may then be tested using these data in conjunction with a quantitative mechanistic framework as opposed to empirical guidelines. To this end, the finite element models that will be created and calibrated in conjunction with experimentally gathered vibratory roller measurements can be used to close the design-construction gap and contribute to improved lifecycle performance of earth structures. The anticipated findings will be valuable to a variety of areas beyond roller-based measurement of soil properties, advance the understanding of the behavior of nonlinear, layered soils subjected to complex dynamic loading scenarios. In addition, a web-based module will be created to integrate recent advances and current research in soil compaction into geotechnical education. The web environment will take advantage of animations, videos, and interaction to convey roller based measurement principles, summarize modulus based measurement techniques, review enabling technologies, and explain modulus-moisture-density fundamentals.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project advanced understanding of vibratory roller-based measurement of layered earthwork properties during construction. It is intuitive that the response of a vibrating drum rolling on soil will be influenced by that soil. One might expect that the amplitude of drum vibration might change as the underlying soil stiffens. Therefore, the measurement of drum vibration can indirectly provide valuable information about the soil. The implications of this are profound. In addition to constructing the earthwork, the operator and field engineer can continuously monitor the state of the soil. The shift from individual location or spot testing of soil that is currently used to continuous complete coverage monitoring using the very roller compactor that prepares the soil results in the significant improvement in quality testing, from testing 0.01% of the earthwork in current practice to testing 100% of the earthwork. This sea change improvement in monitoring has the potential to dramatically improve the performance of highways, roads, bridges and embankments. By providing better monitoring approaches, earthwork professionals can build higher quality facilities that will perform better and last longer.

The research contributed to this advancement by examining the relationship between vibratory drum rollers and layered soil systems, a common situation in construction. While our intuition suggests the vibrating drum holds information about the underlying ground, vibrating drum interaction with layered soil systems is complex. Many questions exist, e.g., which soil layer(s) is the drum vibration sensitive to? what properties of the soil layers influence drum vibration? can we measure the energy dissipation parameters of soil based on drum vibration response? how do layers impact this? To answer these questions, we developed accurate computational models of this complex interaction using finite element analysis software combined with extensive field testing data. The computational models, supported with field data, were then used to better understand what we can measure about the layered soil system by using the drum vibration data. Our study yielded a number of important findings. First, the elastic modulus (stiffness) and thickness of each layer play a significant role in the nature of vibratory drum response. When the top layer becomes thin and/or much stiffer than the underlying layer, the top layer becomes invisible to the vibrating drum, i.e., the drum cannot sense the top layer. This is very important in that field personnel using roller based vibratory measurements on this stiff layers are in fact not measuring the thin stiff layer.  Secondly, we were able to extract material damping properties from measured vibratory (to soil stiffness) that can be used to remotely assess soil compaction. We also advanced research in wave propagation based estimation of stabilized earthwork and electrical signature generation and measurement during vibratory loading of fluid saturated soils.

The project involved two investigators, six graduate students (3 PhD, 3 MS) and six undergraduate students. Four of the paticipants were female. All of the students received significant specialized training in technical topics, the conduct of high level research, and in writing and oral communication.
